clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Oxytocin on Face Perception
clinical_study.official_title: The Behavioral and Neural Effects of Oxytocin on Face Perception in Congenital Prosopagnosia

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine whether oxytocin affect face perception

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Crossover Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Subject, Investigator), Primary Purpose: Basic Science

primary_outcome.description: At the day participants will administer the substance, they will view a set of faces, of which they will be tested about 24 hours later. The measures that will be tested are accuracy and eye movements.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Before oxytocin/placebo uptake, and 45 min. after
secondary_outcome.description: Participants will fill a PANAS mood questionnaire just before oxytocin/placebo uptake, and 45 minutes after oxytocin/placebo uptake, in order to monitor the effects of mood and fatigue of oxytocin/placebo.

arm_group.description: Control group will be administered oxytocin and placebo, in a double-blind randomized order.
CP will be administered oxytocin and placebo in a double-blind randomized order.

intervention.description: Intervention will be examined on control group, and on experimental group as well.
Placebo will be given to control group and experimental group as well.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- normal or corrected to normal vision
Exclusion Criteria:
- minors
- pregnancy (according to a pregnancy test taken by subjects prior to participation)
- a history of asthma or nasal polyps
- cardiac disorders
- hyponatremia
- acute or chronic renal insufficiency
- liver cirrhosis
- neurological disease
- other chronic disease
- dementia, or lack of judgment
